comments.commentBody: Apple products are certainly not perfect but they come pretty close to performing at a level beyond the others.  Android has some excellent attributes, too.  But, in my mind's eye, the iPhone 5, iPad both remain at the top for what most folks need and want.  They are easy to use and just feel good in my hands.  And there's one other thing.  The iphone still seems to be what most people, young and old alike, aspire to have.  Over the past week, I drove over 1500 miles up and down the east coast and everywhere I looked those who were using their phones had iPhones, either 4, 5 or 5c/s.  I have a few friends who love their Android Galaxy, Nexus, et al, but they are "few". I, for one do believe that Apple will continue to flourish and produce some amazing stuff.  But as noted by so many, patience is required.

Checking back over the last few years, an increase of 5.4% or more in health care premiums was not unusual - and in many cases was actually much higher - so for the WSJ to imply that this year's increase is due to the ACA is spurious if not disingenuous.

The WSJ: "It is difficult to determine precisely what impact the Affordable Care Act has had on insurance premiums. Insurance companies say fees and coverage mandates in the law have forced them to raise their rates 5.4%."

I have no doubt on the veracity of the VA claims of protracted wait times, and poor health care delivery. For me, the "scandal" is simply a reminder that we owe our vets the health care they earned overseas. From Social Security to VA health care benefits, the social contract can never be broken.

But I am very concerned by the above statement in today's WSJ. There is going to be a lot of noise next fall as folks begin the process of renewing their plans. The article describes how consumers are going to have to do some major jockeying between carriers as rates are raised on the left hand, and lowered on the right, so it's mostly a wash, but with a projected 5.4% hike in premiums, on average, it's a hard pill to swallow.

Are we to wait in anticipation in the years ahead, hoping the insurance companies don't squeeze the consumer with the power of federal law behind them in their price gauging, as Dr. Krugman so carefully delineated?

The ACA is as unfinished as the Constitution was prior to the Civil War. It just needs to be adjusted to protect the consumer, and perhaps as an added bonus, throw in a "public option" for economically-distressed Americans?

You say politicians recognize attacks on elderly socialized medicine, Medicare, is political suicide? Then why do they keep attacking them, using the budget deficit threats? It's not political suicide here, as it would be in other countries, if any poll tried to do it, which they're not, it seems, despite austerity spending. Can you explain this difference?

Our conservatives also don't seem worried that health care costs hurts our 'competitiveness', whatever that really means. Which is strange, and goes unexplained by our media.
They're only concerned with govt being too big and regulating too much, for obvious reasons. This is what gets all the discussion on media.

Having had US socialized medicine most of my life, I thank Mr Krugman for stating reality so clearly. Military healthcare was superb. When I flew with the British RAF, their healthcare was superb. In the US, politicians recognize attacks on elderly socialized medicine, Medicare, is political suicide. As an executive for European companies, I realized the huge advantage that socialized medicine provide European companies. Facts are that the US inability to control healthcare costs handicaps our competitiveness and hurts our people

I have had great care at Kaiser in San Francisco.

I'm sorry to hear what happened to you. But for many, care at Kaiser is great!
Connsume Reports rates Kaiser groups among the very best in their annual report.

It's true that the Veterans health plan is excellent with great care no matter who would turn it on its head to make a right wing point. But Dr. Krugman is very accurate about Americans getting short changed and being very unhappy with their health care or lack of it. I am a Medicare recipient who chose Kaiser because it was all I could afford. I have paid a high price for belonging to an HMO. They get paid whether they give you are care or not. I had a bike accident and their head plastic surgeon refused me care leaving me with a huge hole in my cheek untended for months and still never attended to leaving a large red ugly scar on my cheek. Even my primary care doctor would not give me antibiotics so I went to an ER and ended up with another Kaiser doctor who was told to do nothing. I was frightened and helpless to help myself. As I talk to more Kaiser members most of them have received inferior or no care as Kaiser members. By the way Medicare pays Kaiser over $10,000 a year to do nothing. Kaiser makes billions each year denying care. But they spent fortune lobbying in Washington. HMOs are not reliable nor do they give good care to a large number of patients. Why not publish their name. They are the one that harms so many patients. Soon to be an ex Kaiser member.

You are right at that the liberal PCUSA church is bleeding members fast.  However, the conservative, bible-believing PCA, Reformed Presbyterians, and Orthodox Presbyterians are doing well.  Our church has experienced enormous growth in the last decade, mostly because people who were abandoned by the liberal "churches" were looking for a place that still preached the Bible. Please give some specific citations to back up your contentions on the merger activity. I'm a PC(USA) teaching elder (pastor/minister) and in my career in four presbyteries in three states, north and south, have never once heard about all these merger plans.

Very true but what gets missed in these revisions is that the people Christ touched changed their lives. Jesus didn't say go ahead and keep sinning I'll tolerate you. Folks are confusing compassion with mandatory acceptance.

What this article does NOT say is that the Presbyterian Church -- like most of the mainstream Protestant churches -- has been hemorrhaging members as it has steadily liberalized and become more focused on social activism instead of religious faith.

I think this will merely hasten the end or diminishment of the Presbyterians -- an acceleration into irrelevance. If you stand for nothing, eventually you ARE nothing.
not to mention that the economy went belly up in 2001 and the "donut hole" phenomenon also took a part in folks trying to find care.

Put two and two together:

1) A higher number of users are in the VA system because a) we just wrapped up a series of conflicts and b) Vietnam vets are coming into their twilight years where they need the most care.

2) One of our political parties is obsessed with defunding the government, or rather, the parts of the government they don't like.

It's not hard to see why the VA system is under considerable strain. It certainly is not a reflection on the merits of public v. private health care financing models, regardless of whatever Dr. Ben Carson thinks. Dr. Ben Carson may (or may not) be an actual doctor, but he knows next to nothing about financing the delivery of care.

There are no doubt many here who remember the great old Flip Wilson sketches of Reverend Leroy, the pastor of the Church of What's Happenin' Now.

The Presbyterian Church is the ultimate Church of What's Happenin' Now. I was a member for decades, including of some of its judicatories, so I know a bit about it.

What is it, Ms. Byers: the General Assemblies who voted against all this many times in the past were wrong, but the latest one is right? What's happenin' now, is always where it's at with the Presbys!

Trust me when I say that most members of the PCUSA haven't the faintest idea who John Calvin was. John Knox is even more obscure. Most have never heard of the Westminster Confession or Catechism. Both doctrinal sources have been bound into a "Book Of Confessions" combining doctrinal texts that contradict it yet the Elders claim to believe the teachings of each. I doubt you'd find a copy of Calvin's Institutes Of The Christian Religion anywhere in a PCUSA church unless it's in the pastor's library.

NY Huguenot: I do hope you are correct in stating that "most members of the PCUSA haven't the faintest idea who John Calvin was (and) John Knox is even more obscure."

If anything is an "abomination" I think the teachings of those two puritans certainly fit the bill.
So stay Methodist. I and my Dutch, French, German and Scottish Calvinists ancestors have and will remain Calvinists.
Blessings on the Presbyterians. If Calvin's offspring can do it, so can the rest of the nominal and devout Christians.

The only "alternative" form of marriage in the Bible is polygamy (one man, several wives). This was the norm in the Middle East long before Christianity or Judaism arose. And Judaism cast off polygamy more than two thousand years ago.

Even so -- polygamy is still a "male/female" form of marriage that respects biology and kinship relations. Gay marriage is not. Polygamy has existed in societies for many thousands of years. Gay marriage is a fad of the last DECADE.
The passage you cite does make me wonder why the Christian churches are not fighting to make divorce illegal.

I always advise vegetarians that they needn't be obsessed with protein. Most people do get enough. I would look at foods like eggs and dairy products as terrific protein sources. I myself tend to get more of my protein at breakfast and lunch, when I eat yogurt, cottage cheese, that sort of thing, than at dinner, when I focus more on vegetables. I am assuming you are not vegan. In that case this advice won't work. The chapters from The Simple Art of Vegetarian Cooking that work best, if you don't want to get too much starch, , are Soups, Big and Small; Frittatas and Omelets; Gratins; Stir-fries; some recipes from Tacos and Quesadillas; and Savory Pies.

I've been a vegetarian for about three years, not really through health concerns but because I happened to have the experience of being at a slaughterhouse.  So, here's my question - - my vegetarian diet is just too starchy.  I love beans and rice, but whoa, starch galore. Tofu, great, but how much tofu can a person eat?  I am not one of the slender wood nymphish vegetarians, and I think the root of my problem is too much starch, too many carbs, not enough protein that is carb free.  Answer that, if you please, Martha Rose!

I use the VA as my secondary health care system. Its employees mean well and try hard, they really do, but it's exhausting. The systems are inefficient and needlessly complex. It needs targeted improvements in systems to improve effectiveness and reduce complexity. That said, if you ever need anything, the VA does it--eventually. They are concerned with efficacy and not cost.

I don't use the VA for most care because it just takes too long and is too hard to navigate. I can see my primary care doctor in a day or two with a simply phone call. The VA doesn't work like that.

M Mahin: A watch is finely tuned for the purpose of telling time.  The probability that a watch came into existence through natural processes is low; it is much more likely that it had a designer.  We know this from experience of many watches and other middle-sized objects, our experience of their use, and our acquaintance with human designers.  We observe a constant conjunction, to use Hume's term, of things that are suited to certain purposes, on the one hand, and designers, on the other.  But should we regard the universe in an analogous way, and say that because it is well suited (appears finely tuned) to support intelligent life it probably had a designer?  I don't see why.  We have experience of only one universe.  We don't know why the physical constants have the values they have, or whether these values would have a low or high probability if there were no intelligent designer.  The universe's fine-tuning suggests a creator *to us* because we make the analogy between a watch and the universe.  But the cases are not alike.

I couldn't agree more. That year was the final time I watched the Oscars *or* listened to Roger Ebert. It also didn't hurt Haggis that his Scientology friends voted their "religion" rather than their artistic taste.

Mr. Haggis was pretty much running on empty when he did Crash as well.  Unhappily, Roger Ebert decided that there was more there than met the eye (or that every human being in southern California was a closet racist) and managed to convince guilt-ridden Oscar voters that it was a better film than Brokeback Mountain.

What a 2,000+ yeast old book, shaped by the prejudices of the time, has to say is all but irrelevant. It's like relying on Hippocrates to tell you how to read an EKG. God, if he exists, surely reveals himself more through reason, compassion, and his creations than dusty old books.

My wife and I were married by a justice of the peace, and that has great significance because it was performed by a government "that recognizes that all of God's children were truly created equal, and are all loved equally."

As an ordained Elder of the Presbyterian Church, USA, I could not be more pleased that our Church has voted to uphold marriage equality for all people. My wife and I were married in the Church 33 years ago, and to my mind that officiation by the Presbyterian Church now has greater significance, because it performed by a Church that recognizes that all of God's children were truly created equal, and are all loved equally.
I know Presbyterians will be thriving in 100 years.

Hopefully the United Methodist Church will now follow the lead of the Presbyterians and do the same in regard to same sex marriages and will end putting on trial ministers who perform same sex marriages.
Please, do not pretend that all Christians share in your views.

A for profit system clearly has inefficiencies. Likewise, a system such as the VA where quality of care is marginal, where wait times are long, where records are systemically doctored to cover up the problem, and where those responsible for the problems are rarely held accountable is not acceptable either.
The for profit system is inefficient, but single payer may likely be worse. Look at the government's ineptitude in caring for those who most deserve quality care, our veterans. They can't get that right, and yet you want to hand them over administering healthcare for the other 320 million of us.

Dear Fernando the LDS recognizing same sex marriage would be a certifiable miracle.  However, I never believed a mainstream religion such as the Presbyterian Church would accept same sex couples either.  Lets hope.

Please distinguish between Presbyterians. Only the PCUSA has endorsed this behavior. The Presbyterian Church In America, The Bible Presbterian Church, The Orthodox Presbyterian Church, The Evangelical Presbyteran denominations do not. Cumulatively we are larger than the Mainlne PCUSA we all left over the last 80 years.
I wonder if the Church of the Latter Day Saints (Mormons) will be the next one to make these changes in the way they treat gay couples.

Excellent points. But Republicans don't have to loudly proclaim that something doesn't work. They assimilate the cause of something rather than logically thinking it through. Watch for higher gas prices around election time. Obama did it. I guarantee it.

General Motors' scandal involves ignition systems. 14 to 17 people died resulting from GM ignition failures. Managers who should have been coordinating responses didn't. Engineers and lawyers who should have taken action either passed the buck or found excuses to avoid taking corrective action. People have been fired, others transferred, a few may be criminally liable, and corrective action is being taken.

Are Republicans loudly proclaiming that this is proof our capitalist-based automotive manufacturing system doesn't work ... and should be replaced? Of course not.

The VA scandal is similar. In certain sections, managers and administrators failed in their responsibilities and some may be criminally liable. As with GM, people responsible are being or will be fired, some transferred, and corrective actions taken.

Yet Republicans, in all their hypocritical glory, are howling how the entire system failed and should be abandoned.

Britain's well-functioning NHS also has sections mismanaged occasionally or bad practitioners cause harm. They're replaced, the system corrected, and it continues to work.

Apparently Republicans, who proclaim to be the party of business, don't know squat about the practical operation of business and commerce systems.

A large part of the VA scandal occurred in McCain's Arizona. Surely veterans contacted his office with complaints. Why was McCain's response so ineffective his office failed to uncover the fraud?
